title: TM1638 module mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
A simple mount for TM1638 module (JY-LKM1638 of dealextreme: http://www.dealextreme.com/p/81873?r=68099021 ) You can move the axis, debug your sensors or wathever you want with this module. You can use this easy library to programe your firmware:
http://code.google.com/p/tm1638-library/

It clamps onto the front threaded rod of the frame and will fit m8. It also includes two little holes for mounting TM1638 module with 2 M3 bolts. I used 4 M3x10 bolts to fit it with the other bolts that come with the module when you bought it, but you can use 4 M3x20 bolts without them. To assemble this mount, you'll need:
-Print two lkm1638BoardMount.stl.
-Four M3x20 or M3x20 bolts and nuts.
-Two M4x20 bolts and nuts. Enjoy ;)

description.text:
M4 Hop-up Unit for an Airsoft Gun. Should work with any TM Compatible Airsoft Gun.

Been looking for an 3D Printable Hop-up and None where available, So i ported an Model Created By an user on GrabCad user to STL files.

Some sanding / cleanup may be required to get the parts to fit well.

I also found that Printing the Adjustment Wheel with an 101-105 scale helps to get it fit better.

All Credit for the Model Files goes to Szilagyi Laszlo Over at GrabCad. I only Ported this to STL files So it can Be Printed.

I included the Model for the 0-ring of anyone wants to Try a Flexible Filament. or you can buy an O-ring from an hardware Store

I also included the Peg for the Hopup Arm. I used an Piece of 1.75mm filament as it fit perfectly.

Printer:

Prusa I3 mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1mm or lower

Infill:

20% at least

Notes:

Build plate only Support may help Only Use Bed Plate Support to Prevent Blockage of Chamber, and Easy clean up

Printing the parts at 1.06 and the Adjustment Wheel at 1.08 Scale on Cura may help if your barrel and Bucking fit to snug.

description.text: Lazio Roma - Logo

Handy and stylish wallet for cash, coins, documents and cards. Just print it!

Most precious things are inside, but if you want to take few coins quickly you just turn the switch and you can easily pour the money.

If you like this design, please donate (blue button on the right - Tip Designer) , so i will have more time for putting more interesting projects here.

If you want to have your individual one, with your logo or other picture ( character, face, whatever) with your own wallet size ( want bigger or smaller? no problem!) for a small donation, just write to me [email protected]

Have a nice wallet!
Cheers

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,15

Infill:

doesn't matter

Notes:

IMPORTANT---
To make Wallet's Switch work well, print all parts with Z RESOLUTION - 0.15mm.---
SUPPORT isn't really neccesary, but some printers may have a problem with one tricky place - switch hole in CAP part of the Wallet. You may need support there. ---
Model should be printed SLOW to make layers bounded well. It will make wallet stronger, which is very important if you want to wear it in your pocket.

Sanding

If you print fast or your 3d printer doesn't print precisely, you will need a sandpaper or even better a nail file, to smooth the surfaces, especially inside of the Wallet.

Better to do it, to have a Wallet working well.

The idea is simple. Came to me when I started to be fed up with my older big wallet. It was to big to wear it in the pocket.

I decided to create something handy, but big enough to carry all my valuable things like cash, documents, credit cards and few coins.

Designed wallet is really funcional. Most precious things are inside, but if you want to take few coins quickly you just turn the switch and you can easily pour the money.

There are three pockets on the BASE part:

-lowest for cash

-middle height for coins

-highest for documents and cards

Just put all that can merge inside.

author: chev383

description.text:
A horizontally scaled variant of @mscourch's tank track design. I've also tweeked the links for using "Tie wire" as rivets, which is ~2mm wide. Added holes in the sides, to tuck the wire nubs into, to keep them from falling out (or stabbing your hand, as tie wire tends to be sharp) Track:
50mm wide (20mm was default)
~2.8mm hole width (3.3mm was default, I want to go down to 2.3mm but got sick of battling SketchUp to fill it correctly)
Side holes are 2.4mm tall, 1mm wide, 1mm deep Driver Wheel:
18mm wide (was 6mm). I tried 15mm wide, and it adds some slop/play, which im not sure is desireable or not yet. The 18mm fits with about 1mm clearence on each side. I've successfully printed the first one. The first things I want to change, is to double the size and depth of the pin retention holes.
A holder for the popular phone in gliding: Dell Streak. Made it for personal use with a RAM mount or similar. The center hole may or may not suit your needs.

print_settings.Notes:: 2 vertical and horizontal bottom shell. 3 horizontal top shell.

title: Yet Another Utility Blade Holder (YAUBH)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I need a utility blade holder that is compact, strong, easy to clean and reasonably safe for pocket carry. The holder comprises of two part that is clipped together. The utility blade could be placed in two positions by a frame lock catch. Default setting is for a right-hand user, a standard utility blade and a holder thickness of 5mm.

Safety: The safest way to hold the blade is to grip the holder at the frame lock using your thumb and index finger. This ensures that the blade does not slip. You could also grip the frame lock using your thumb and middle finger while placing your index finger on the jimping to allow precise control of the blade.

The blade thickness and width could be adjusted to obtain a snug fit. Option for left-handed user is available (NOT TESTED). Adjustable using OpenSCAD or Customizer (http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1749766)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40% rectiliner

Notes:

2 vertical and horizontal bottom shell. 3 horizontal top shell.
Cleanup may be required. Clip both frame part together and insert a utility blade. Go cut something :)

Idea

I owned a Gerber EAB however I didn't like folding knife mechanism due to cleaning issues. If folding knife is your thing, than see (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1298487). I was inspired by Rexford RUT, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1425716 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1162705. However the current design did not have all the feature I need and difficult to print on my Prusa i3.

Design

I went through several design shown in the image below evaluating the strength and weakness of each. Here's a few design note
a. Frame lock used 1 notch blade catch instead of two since it is strong enough. As an added benefit, the blade can be held in two position
b. The frame consist of two plate and is held together by a three clip. The early design used plastic filament rivets but I found out that the frame bend due to the heat while riveting.

Design iteration from left to right Beta version

The beta version was tested extensively. I've been using the holder for a few days and it held well for cutting, slicing and light prying. The beta version blade catch was placed at the second notch of the utility blade. This was a design mistake that caused the blade loose in close position. The frame clip is not tight enough for my liking. Other than these issues, the blade holder performs well.

Two plate frame with clip Two position for the utility blade Hold by pressing both index finger and thumb Pruning a small Red Palm Cutting plastic bottle (PETE) plant container Dirty holder and blade Final version

The final version retain all the best features from beta version. I moved the frame lock catch to the first position and cut at a slant at the blade insert to increase the blade to handle ratio. The resulting area on top of the blade allows me to add back jimping. A finger plate was added to the top side of the frame and a total of four stronger clip was placed around the frame.

This design is for a Printrbot with  threaded rods at the base,  Y and X smooth rods, and a  sq. heated bed. The design is ~10.5 in. by ~13 in.
There's also a design that is made up of 4 pieces which attach together with 8 short #6 bolts.
There are 2 pairs of 2 holes for the belt clamps.
There are 4 holes closest to the middle for mounting a  x  heated build plate.
The 4 holes closest to the outside are for the Y Bar Clamps.
02/17 Update: Made the Y-bar holes wider to allow for some slop in the distance between each of the bases.
02/19 Update: Corrected position of the belt clamps. The belt clamp needed to line up with the edge of the 608 bearings.
02/21 Update: Added length. Hot end doesn't line up with x smooth rods, so there needs to be extra length on the right or left side of the print bed. Also made the holes wider for #6 bolts.
03/01 update: adjusted position of belt clamps 
03/09 update: rounded edges slightly
05/01 update: attached a design for a 4 piece print bed, because the laser cutter I have access to can't cut the 13+ inch original design
I'm planning to remove nearly all the material in the center of the plate (to reduce weight/momentum/wobble).

title: Compact Bowden Extruder with 20-20 profile fitting

description.text:
This is a compact simple, low cost, lever arm extruder, with a simple groove bearing and flat driving gear that is more than capable of driving 1.75mm filaments.

MaxMicron printers have somewhat poorly designed and printed components, and the extruder is critical. If it cracks or breaks you'll need a replacement that can hopefully be printed with the remaining extruder if you got a dual extruder setup....

The extruder design that comes with the MaxMicron can bend, as the motor is not supported properly at the side on the bracket. This design fixes that, giving a very solid mounting.

The drive gap is as small as possible for flexible filament types, and the components are extremely strong if printed in PLA with the right orientation. It simply reuses the hardware from the existing extruder being replaced. Otherwise if making a new extruder you'll need:

  • NEMA17 47nm stepper with 5mm shaft, flat ground
  • 11mm brass gear, sharp flat teeth to fit with grub screws
  • 12mm diam 4mm deep 2mm groove bearing for pressure
  • 2x M5 x15mm bolt and tee nuts for mounting to profile
  • 1x M4 x12mm bolt to mount groove bearing
  • 3x M3 x 20mm long mounting bolts
  • 1x M3 x 6mm short mounting bolt
  • 1x Extruder spring

You may be able to adapt to fit a Mk7 or Mk8 drive. I like this one as the groove bearing is a thin 4mm component, keeping the design compact. The sharp gear bites nicely, but is limited by the rim of the groove bearing, giving a consistent grip.

Some heat forcing to get fittings to bed into their holes is needed, so some care is needed in assembly. Once built it works great. The mounting bracket is for the 20-20 profile of the MaxMicron printer and other similar builds, and it is easy to edit the scad file to make a bracket for 30 or 40mm profile.

The mounting M3 hex head bolts are all recessed, and a short M3 hex head can be used instead of the countersunk phillips head short screw underneath the spring arm that came with the original extruder

Printer:

MaxMicron Modified

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm layers, 0.4mm tip, 0.5mm width

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Print the base with no supports. Print the arm with supports, I used Slic3r and pillars/0.2 detachable. The arm must be printed in the orientation given. It is essential to set for 5 perimeters, and 5 layers for top and bottom. 40% or higher filling. PLA is excellent and quite strong enough for this design.

Assembly

Attach the base to the 20-20 frame, one bolt is hidden once the motor is in place.

Fit the gear to the motor, approximately positioned on shaft. Fit the motor to the base plate using the short M3 and two long M3 bolts, and tighten until recessed. The fit should be tight with no play. If it won't quite fit you may need to adjust your extrusion flow and or other slicer settings and try again, the tolerances are 0.1-0.25mm.

Adjust the gear until it is centred around the filament hole and tighten.

Clear the arm slot support material, and put the grove bearing in place and hot screw the M4 retaining bolt into place. Print another arm in case you over do the heating(!) I print them in pairs but you don't have to if you are good with a lighter or soldering iron. :) Keep it square! It is a tight fit but you don't want it coming loose during operation.

Put the spring roughly in place in the holder cup, and holding the arm with the retaining bump in the other end of the spring, you need to squeeze enough to get the arm hinge bolt into place, this takes some time and effort. Someone clever will come up with a clamping jig, but I just persist.

If you have attached near the top of your 20-20 frame it is convenient to hold the extruder while you hot seat the PTFE fitting, , but you may want to do that first before assembly if your final location is not accessible.

Hot fitting, M4 bolt and M6 PFTE fitting

The 5.2mm hole for the M6 PTFE fitting needs to be tapped using a hot M6 screw (do not heat the PFTE fitting, it will melt the blue release flange internally and ruin the fitting [ I know!] ). You may also be able to an M6 tapping tool to help, but heat should be enough. Remember, take it slow or you'll be spending another 3 hours to print a new base....

Clear the support material from the arm slot and then carefully push/twist fit a hot M4 bolt through the outer arm, through the bearing and just to the inside edge of the through hold.
Slowly and with minimum of heat (a gas lighter frequently used for short bursts between pushing for a few seconds at a time

Fitting M6 hole after careful screwing with a hot M6 bolt. With the PFTE fitting fitted, and the M4 bolt is though the arm holding the groove bearing.

Design

OpenSCAD Rules :)

description.text:
I was having clogging issues due to the hot end becoming too warm. In order to solve this I designed this cooling tube to improve the air flow to the cooling fins of the hot end.

Specifically made to fit the e3d-lite6 hotend and a 40x40mm fan. The cabling of the hot end should go around the carriage; if you guide it towards the back side of the printer it shouldn't get into the way of any parts.

I recommend using a bit of tape (I used electrical tape) to close any seam between the fan and the duct.

Printer:

FuseBox 1.4

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Doesn't matter as the part is very thin.

Notes:

I printed this at 0.2mm because due to the cooling issues mentioned I couldn't print at any other resolution reliably; this might be different for your printer. A brim is advisable to prevent the part from falling over while printing.

5 sept: Support removal can be tricky for the duct, I haven't found a 100% working solution for placement and design yet due to the size constraints within the carriage

5 sept: Added a slightly modified carriage design. It is based on the "newcarriage" made by AlexY. The main change is the removal of a small ridge in the center hole; with this you don't need to remove it manually after printing. The duct will still fit the original one with a bit of sanding.
As per the instructions of the original carriage, it should be printed with 3 perimiters and 30% infill.

Assembly Instructions

First mount the hot end, then slide this part over it from the top. It should fit right between the hot end and the carriage on the back side of the carriage (the side facing the rear of the printer). It may be required to remove a slight bit of material from the carriage to fit it, as the fit is rather tight.

No screws or tape are required to hold it in place because it takes a little force to put it in and pull it out.

comments.text:
After persistent heavy coggling issues caused by unwise hotend carriage design, it seems to me that your salvific cooling tube resolve my problems. Thank you very much!
I've tried very big fan, I've added thin walls for redirect air flow, either combination of temperature but my e3d standard extruder didn't work properly. With your add-on it's OK!

title: Integral Bearing Lib
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A very simple lib to generate a shape to cut integral bearings out of another object

custombearing(height, innerdiameter, gapsize, contactheight, facets); Usage:
include <integralBearingLib.scad>; difference() {
cylinder(r=10,h=20,center=true);
custombearing(20,12);
} Parameters:
  • height - height of the object the bearing is being cut from
  • innerdiameter - diameter of the inner rings that will contact the shaft
  • gapsize - distance between the inner diameter and the diameter inside the bearing where it is not contacting the shaft
  • contactheight - height of the ring that contacts the surface
  • facets - number of facets used in the bearing

description.text:
This is a work-in-progress version of my redesign of AlexY's cold end for the FuseBox 1.4. The part of it that holds the bearing (I called it the rollerblade) kept breaking, so I changed the sharp inner edge by a curved one to alleviate internal stresses. I also modified it so it fits my drive gear, which is larger than the one used by AlexY.

As you can see from the pictures, the servo axle and the bearing are not level at the moment. This is something I intend to fix, but due to licensing issues I am currently not able to use SolidWorks to do so.
The same goes for the washers in between the servo part and the servo; a small cut-out is needed on the backside to eliminate the need for these.

author: Marcykemhed

description.text:
This is the second file publish of my robotic arm series. This component is the turntable of the robotic arm.

The following hardware will be needed to assemble the gripper:

  • M3 x 10mm round head(25x)
  • M3 x 8mm round head (8x)
  • M3 x 3mm grub screw (1x)
  • M4 x 3mm grub screw (1x)
  • M4 x ...mm (5x), length for bottom plate bolts will depend on your wooden base plate thickness.
  • 10mm x 30mm x 9mm bearing, 6200zz (2x)
  • 10mm steel balls (10x)

The following electronic parts will be needed:

  • Nema 17 (34mm height) stepper motor
  • BOURNS 3590S 10 turn potentiometer

The assembly should be pretty straight forward, just follow the exploded view. Questions?? Message me!

Notes:

  • Print the bearing clamp twice!
  • All critical holes are oversized by 0.25mm to guarantee an easy fit.
  • All the M3 / M4 holes are sized 2.8mm / 3.8mm in diameter. Apply some grease (not necessary, but it makes it easier) on a normal bolt and screw them in the parts with some proper tools. This should make some neat and tight threads in the plastic.
  • While assembling, make sure the potentiometer is rotated to the center (5 turns). Next align the notch of the rotating plate with the potentiometer and push the rotating plate in place.
  • Apply some light oil or grease on the 10mm steel balls.

Printer:

Craftbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15% - 25%

Base top and rotating plate ball guide

Both the circular ball guide from the base top plate and the rotating plate can be sanded with some fine sandpaper to improve the rotational capabilities of the turntable.

comments.author: WonderTiger

comments.text: Indeed it should be a good replacement for normal hobby servos and at the same time a cheaper alternative to the dynamixel servos. At the moment the Smart Servos are at the beginning of the design phase. The custom PCB contains some basic components like a DC motor driver, RS-485 transceiver, linear power supply and a 8-bit microcontroller from Microchip. I briefly tested the different components to see if they worked, and everything be fine. However there is still a ton of stuff to do on those Smart Servos ;). At the moment I'm developing a custom bootloader so I can program the microcontrollers over RS-485 (might even consider to implement chain programming, so all the servos in the chain can be programmed at the 'same' time) as I did not had any room left for a dedicated ICSP program header. After the bootloader is completed I will start working on the PID controller, communication scheme and a general interfacing library, as you can see I've got plenty to do ;). If you're interested I can keep you updated on the progress of the servo's, just send me a message with your e-mail.

Nice work!
What about encoder? Do you rely on the original (and low quality) potentiometer? Or do you plan to change it, maybe switch to another solution, like magnetic encoder?
Another question: why RS485 and not I²C?
BTW, it seems you are using TowerPro clones (I don't see the capacitors on the motor); original MG99x have slightly different dimensions, so check for your final PCB: it would be pity not to be able to use original TowerPro servos (which have less gear backlash).
comments.author: WonderTiger

comments.text: Yes, at first I will use the stock potentiometer. My guess is that the potentiometer will be fine, however I will probably make a device to test the linearity of the stock potentiometer. If the results of these tests are acceptable then I will continue to use the stock potentiometer, otherwise I will buy a better one. I probably won't go with the magnetic encoder solution as this will add complexity and cost, that way you might as well buy a dynamixel servo. But who knows... in the future I might consider a magnetic encoder implementation :).

I think stock potentiometer is not linear at all. What you should do is use a LUT in your firmware, so one can set things really linear if needed. I agree, magnetic encoder is expensive, and not easy to adapt...
comments.author: WonderTiger

comments.text: At LUT might be a good starting point, but again I did not do any real world testing yet. So right now I'm just throwing around some ideas :).
Yeah, you're right, no need to such refresh rate! I think giving a new position 10 times per second is enough to make smooth trajectories. Good :o)
comments.author: WonderTiger

comments.text: The PCB on the pictures is the first version, it will probably undergo some modifications in the future. At the moment I'm using the same connector as the one that comes delivered with the servo, but instead of 3 pins it will have 4 (Vdd, DAT+, DAT- and GND). The drawback of these connectors are their height. The backcover will have to be about 10mm longer so that it will be flush with the back of the connectors. In my opinion this isn't optimal, so I will look for another type in the future.
No, the rotation shaft is opposite to motor : it is just above the PCB, aligned with the potentiometer...
comments.author: WonderTiger

comments.text: Whoops. You are right!! At the moment that will become an issue then, hmmm. I might consider an angled connector then! Tommorow I'm going to do some research :).

description.text: Star Trek: Frontiers has some great models for the player ships and the borg cubes, but lots of the other items in the game are just cardboard tokens. So I took the tokens that represented spaces you're not allowed to remain on and turned them into models that HOLD the tokens.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Make sure your bed adhesion is good because printing these out with rafts makes them extremely difficult to clean. Supports are a good idea for the warbird but the other two should be fine naked. The warbird requires some cleaning but it looks pretty sharp when its done.

I took the warbird model and then solidified it in Tinkercad by strengthening the wispy bits. Sadly at this scale the warbird cannot be fully hollow so I compromised. I'm sure a good painter can make it look awesome.
I used a caliper to measure the tokens and did a number of test prints to get the slots just right so it holds the token securely without being too tight or risking tearing the cardboard.

title: Nook Hook Book for a Kindle K3

description.text:
This is a stand to hold a kindle K3 attached to a lamp stand. I use it to read sitting on an exercise ball or a straight backed chair. This helps with neck pain that is worse when bending forward or looking down. It could also be used while riding an exercise bike or standing. It's called a Nook Hook Book after the character in the Dr. Seuss book "One fish, two fish, red fish, blue fish"

We saw a Nook.
On his head
he had a hook,
On his hook
he had a book.
On his book
was "How to Cook."

It would be an even better name if I had a Barnes and Noble Nook instead of a Kindle!

The brackets are sized for a short horizontal pipe or rod ~16 mm diameter, and a similar long vertical rod. On mine the vertical rod is part of a lamp stand I already had. You'll also need:
4 of 4 by 45 mm bolts
4 of 4 by 20 mm bolts
8 nuts Print two kindle brackets, a post bracket and a post clamp. The clamps have holes for trapped nuts.

description.text:
If I don't say so myself, I think this new tile is grate! Ok, kidding aside, I needed some grates for an upcoming game and wanted to make them so the grate is removable. I've got every size here from 2x2 - 4x4, so this can be for all sorts of fun stuff. Grate covering over ahole between levels? Yep, you can do that now. Giant trapped under a magical grate? yep, that works too.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)

title: Da Vinci 1.0 Y Stepper Motor Bracket (with nuts !)

description.text:
Tweaked the original bracket by lynce9956 to incorporate M3 nuts which I fixed in place with epoxy.
With this bracket and new stepper drivers, I can hardly hear the stepper motors at all now.
The loudest thing is the E3D fan !
I used long pin headers to make an adapter for the stepper drivers by bending the pins into the correct position (the stock drivers are a non standard size and 3rd party drivers don't fit without some modification).
Long pin headers :- http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/121744153610?_trksid=p2059210.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

title: Handout to get kids excited about S.T.E.A.M.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was invited to present some of my work to a group of Girl Scouts from rural Nebraska visiting my university, so I created this handout to give to them all for future reference.
  • Front side introduces the idea of S.T.E.A.M., and lists six influential women that the girls can learn more about on their own. Includes Twitter handles so they can actually interact with them directly, and not need to rely on their teachers and parents for guidance.
  • Back side includes information about the Maker's Movement, hackerspaces, Maker Faires and some of my work.
    • This handout is intended to be given to middle-school or high-school students (specifically girls, due to the event), but I'm including the Photoshop source files (PSDs) so anyone can modify it for their purposes.
Print double-sided using the front and back PDFs or images.

title: Manfred - WW1 RC Model Pilot Bust

description.text:
This is a remix to create a WW1 pilot bust that could be used in RC models. This one has been used in a Sopwith Pup and a Fokker DR1 Triplane both at 1/6 scale.
Using Meshmixer the base was incorporated into the body, the jacket adjusted to represent a period leather one, the pilots headphone incorporated into the helmet along with the helmet altered to be similar to the ones in use at the time. The scarf was removed so a woollen one can be added after to blow in the breeze. It has been printed in pink (Manufacturer refers to it as Skin) PLA at 0.2mm height and 0% fill to reduce weight, It is quite strong enough for the task and very light weight like this, my 1/6 scale version weighed 12.5g. The Pilot was enlarged in Cura to be 86mm shoulder to shoulder size to give 1/6 scale.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Support could be added under his nose and chin, some is there under the chin already, but it's probably more trouble than its worth. Once he's cleaned up and has a coat of paint it can't really be seen.

title: P3Steel Y-axis idler for 5mm bore H-type idler pulley

description.text:
This is a remix of toolson's Y-axis idler, made to use a 5mm bore H-type idler pulley with integrated bearing.

For the P3Steel 2 / 2.5, not sure whether it fits other versions.

I got my bearing here: http://www.banggood.com/20T-5mm-GT2-Timing-Belt-Idler-Pulley-With-Bearing-For-3D-Printer-p-1044832.html?p=1A09031890783201507H

Notes:

Make sure you print it standing up to get the best possible strength along the y-axis. There are supports included but they have a small contact area, so use a brim.
Use the same M3 bolts and flat (non-nyloc) M3 nuts to attach it to the frame. Wrap the belt around the idler and attach it, use a M5 bolt and nyloc nut to fasten, don't overtighten.

This is a two part Wall Mount designed for a Trekstor Surftab Wintron 7 Tablet.

The Tablet can be slidden in and out from the top.
The left part has a cutout to fit most micro-USB Plugs, even larger ones.

I used double sided construction adhesive tape which holds very strong (mine has a rating of 100 kg per meter).

When printing the mounts on the outer left or right side down you don't need any support.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Infill:

15 % is more than enough

Notes:

print with left or right side facing down so you won't have to create support structures.

I chose to print with 2 perimeters and 3 solid top and bottom layers.
The Parts turned out very strong.

Adhesive Tape

Make sure you use a strong adhesive tape that can hold the weight depending on the surface you want it to attach to!

I used Tesa Powerbond Ultra Strong double sided construction tape with a rating of 100 kg per meter of tape which works absolutely fine.

Be sure to apply the tape according to the manual.
I give absolutely no guarantee for falling tablets ;)

description.text: Not being an experienced RC helicopter pilot I find it tips over easily when landing, particularly on grass. This skid set is a direct replacement for the original one and fits the original mounting method. It is longer, wider and higher than the original (see photo) and makes it much easier to land on grass and allows the helicopter to bounce better when landed poorly (often by me). The files need laying flat, I use Cura and they are printed at 0.2mm layer height with 100% fill. I used PLA and that is working really well. The legs fit easily onto the heli frame with original mounting screws. I found the legs needed tweaking slightly to fit in the slots in the skids and were glued in with solvent glue. The fronts of the skids were warmed with a heat gun and curved upwards slightly to stop them digging in on landing

10%

Notes:

14 hour print using standard settings on a 5th gen Makerbot.

Use super glue to attach the magnet to the mounting plate.
Use super glue to attach the chain to the mounting plate and the planter.
Use a big enough magnet to hold up the planter after watering.
The magnet is not strong enough to hold the planter up on vertical surfaces, like a refrigerator. It should be attached to a horizontal surface, like an office overhead cabinet.

title: Root 3 CNC multitool router 3D printed parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
R3!

Official Website!

Join our forum and ask questions with our community.
https://www.rootcnc.com

Info

Current Version = R3

The Updated version of Root2 CNC is here! I have been completely blown away with the community which has been created by this project and listening to all the comments and suggestions made - R3 was created. R3 Is keeping to the same design goals as before, but since then a lot has been learnt and areas for improvements been highlighted. There have been many changes implemented on this revision, some radical and some minor though all the changes have been implemented to increase configurability, rigidity, flexibility, accuracy and also reduce the amount of different parts required.

R3 supports the use of the largest of NEMA23 motors and also the NEMA17s motors depending on the user’s configuration. Its accuracy has also been increased by the removal of the second loop of belt on the Y-Axis whilst still keeping the two side of the gantry still connected together. The second loop of belt introduced a position error when a load was applied to the gantry, now there is only single belt length to increase its positional accuracy. By doing this made it difficult to keep the two sides of the gantry relatives to one another (something another 3D printed CNCs suffer with). Though R3 gantry sides are connected together, so no matter if the machine losses power or is disconnect the machine still stays relevant to one another to keep its running true and square.

Belt or Lead screw? This has been an interesting topic but no matter what your preference is, R3 has provisions for a Lead screws as drive mechanism for both the X and Y Axis. This does require some of your own design work to fit the type of Lead screw the individual is running though the core R3 shouldn’t need any modification and will work with Belt of Lead screws.

Linear Guilds for the Z axis?! I know theses aren’t considered cheap. But once all the variables and benefits have been factored in, they become a compelling option to use. especially for the short lengths the Z axis requires. With the original design there was sufficient play in the carriage, due to its minimalist design. Though R3 has attempted to removed or possibility of play with the wood panel and the use of Linear Guilds. But don’t think this is the only limited to linear guilds, R3 keeps legacy support implementing the same linear bearing style design and also legacy Z carriages.

Build one

Please if you build one, post some photos! I would love to see them!

Own Design Printer

Doesn't Matter

Yes

0.25-0.35

50%

Notes:
  • Strength is key! use the hardest settings possible
  • Print with 3-4 perimeters
  • Print with ABS but PLA will be fine though your mileage may vary

Goals

• Create an expandable CNC machine capable to machine aluminium
• Use minimal different 3D printed parts
• Customization (Make it Bigger, Use different motor and drive methods_
• Cheap
• Simple
• Use parts commonly used in DIY 3D printer
• Easily sourced parts

BOM

See R3.zip for the BOM

BOM in embedded in the .Zip File

CAM Software
  • Generate the Gcode
    I use PathCam, free open source software with minimal settings to enter to get up and running. Its not perfect but still does a great job! see link for more information.

https://github.com/xenovacivus/PathCAM

Revision History

R2.1.1:
-Base
R2.1.2:
-Added Z-Axis Linear Guild Wooden Front & Back Single Compatible Part (.STL)
-Nema23 50mm Spacer (Missing from Original)
-Nema17 50mm Spacer (Missing from Original)
R2.1.3:
-Amended Y Gantry side panel holes to the correct dimensions
R2.1.4:
-Added Mirrored version of the Y axis box mounts
-Added a universal front and rear X carriage Z plate
R2.1.5:
-Added a first rev of the BOM!! (about time hay ;) ). use the filter tab to help configure your setup (requires MS office)
-Added a Connector Panel for G16-4 connectors
-Revised the X axis belt clamps
-Added the missing drag chain mount.
-Added the optional Y gantry bearing cap with added cable management tab.

R3 Working Release
-Tweaked the Z carriages with the new test and also increased the clearance for the Z endstop switches
-Added the Z Probe connector for 4mm bannana plugs
-Tweaked the BOM slightly

Wishlist
-Lead screw mounting for X and Y axis!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=74322

Using the following options: layer_height = 0.2
hole_diameter = 10
number_of_layers = 12
image_file = lithopane20131101-1042-67ljd4-0.dat

print_settings.Notes:: If you have too little or too much play, scale the part(s) up or down a tiny bit in the slicer and it should work.

description.text:
This is a Case for four Rolls of 35 mm Analog Film (135).

One edge has a cutout so the film fits snuggly inside and doesn't wobble around.

It holds rolls with the leader sticking out.

Film is not dead!!!

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Infill:

25 %

Notes:

Support for the Container itself is not necessarily needed. This depends on how well your printer can print the filleted edge on the bottom.
My Wanhao did an excellent job at this and i didn't need any support.

For the Lid you definitely need support as i recommend printing it facing the bottom down on the build plate so you will get a nice top finish (you will not look at the inside eyh).

The Lid fits tight onto the container, the tolerances in the design are 1 mm in the lengthy direction and .5 mm from front to back.

If you have too little or too much play, scale the part(s) up or down a tiny bit in the slicer and it should work.

description.text:
Hi!

Didn't find any 'Wired earths' so i do some tests in Blender.

Now i have four versions. Two icospheres (simple and smoothed) and two UV spheres (simple and smoothed again)

There is 4 files with full spheres and 8 files with the related semispheres. (Used Meshmixer for this)

Also included a STL with a stand.

Some islands dissapear ant may not be the most detailed earth you can find but the wired seas looks really good.

Take care of this one, is our home.

Have fun!

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 or less

Infill:

Doesn´t matter

Notes:

Tested with PLA

I don't use supports because printing time increases too much

I only have overhanging problems printing the icosadron (not smoothed), but after cleaning look nice

At 100% size (about 5 cms diameter) you can print a full globe adding a brim or raft but for bigger sizes i recomend printing the two hemispheres and glue it

author: maartenva

description.text:
I made a simple funnel in openscad a few months ago & needed to change it & decided to make it more customizable. I looked at a few images of funnels on the internet to get an idea of what else to vary in the design & this is what I came up with.

Since there are quite a few variables you can change, I added a screen shot of a drawing showing what each dimension is related to. The Small_Thk dimension is only changable in the downloaded openscad source. I made it the same as Thk for the thingiverse customizable version. I included a STL file of the size I used & this is also the default settings in the openscad script.

I changed the Hook_xx variable names to a more appropriate Eye_xx names after a friend mentioned this.

comments.text:
Very nice!
By the way, which application did you use to create this picture?
comments.author: valba

comments.text: I used DraftSight Pro which is an AutoCAD Clone. Set the background to White, ran the command shadeview with option fLat with edges, then used windows snipping tool to capture the screen area.

comments.text: You are welcome.  There is also a free version of DraftSight if you are interested in an AutoCAD clone.  The only reason I bought the Pro version was the ability to use Lisp programming with it & they had a really good price back in May for the Pro version.  It is not 100% autolisp compatible, but close enough for me.  The free version does everything else that I need it to do.  Here is a link to that site. www.draftsight.com

author: FMM

description.text:
I wanted to create a nice box for the printed settlers of catan tiles. So I came up with this wooden box to store a 6 player game with the water extension pack.

Attached you will find a pdf with a detailed list of required wooden pieces. I had a carpenter cutting this parts on his cnc cutter, but a friendly guy in the next home improvement store should be fine.

Start from the bottom plate and glue the outer parts on it. the spacers to the left and right will then be used to place the floors on top of it.

For the drawers, glue them together without the front part, put it into the finished box and hold the front to make sure it is absolutely narrow. Use some wax on the downside and the sides of the drawer to make it work smoother.

For the lid to be attached, you will need a hinge like this: https://www.amazon.de/13916-Stangenscharnier-32x900mm-Edelstahl-Klavierband/dp/B000VD9944/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1472840410&sr=8-3&keywords=klavierband.

Also you will need to create a 45 degree phase to the connection point between the cap and the box. You can easily sand it or use a rotary tool if available.

After all, oil the wood on all surfaces to get a nice shiny look. Glue some textile to the inside of the lid to protect the tiles from bumping into the wood during rough transport and add some locks like these:https://www.amazon.de/Schloss-f%C3%BCr-Schatullen-mehr-bronze/dp/B00XZR93JE/ref=pd_sim_201_4?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=Q4KWG4HTMHCCBX50N50C

I know that this description might not be as detailed as you might need it. So if you have any questions on how to proceed, please ask. i'm happy to help you out and improve my description.

For the inlay, see these parts I used:
Tile Holder of rthe top: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1749597
Card holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1749619
Border piece holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1749612
Playing Piece Boxes: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:466723 with the inlay http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1234078

Note: the pictures do not show the version uploaded here completely. After finishing the box, I realized two or three drawbacks in the original design and improved it. therefor there are only two drawers instead the original 2. I also added the spacers for easier attachment of the floors.

Update 11.12.2016: I now finally found the time to update this thing and added the requested front part. It's splitted up in 3 parts each to make it printable.
I also added a german version of the name plate for all of you who want to play it in the original language.

title: Seburo M5 Ghost in the Shell, and Appleseed

description.text:
This is a fictional Seburo M5 pistol used in Ghost in the Shell as well as by Deunan Knute from Appleseed. I did not model this myself, it has come to me via a 3rd party who has assured me I am allowed to share this model freely. I do not  take credit for the original model but it has been vastly modified from its pepakura original so that it can print on a 3D printer in parts.  
If you are the original artist or know who is, please let me know and I will update the attribution accordingly

Model of Tracer from Heroes of the Storm
Extracted from this repo and cleaned up in Blender and Netfabb.

UPDATE: Based on feedback I have edited the model to be more printable. The 2.0 poses should print with your slicer's supports. The older models have geometry issues and you should only print these if your slicer has a self-filling wrapping function or if you want to edit them.

Also included is the .blend file so you can export your own poses! Use the Armature's action editor to select posts. Browse the frames in the FR: menu. Then export as .stl.
